Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. div.head: Lord Kelvin's Death.
div.p: Yesterday telegrams announce the death of the greatest modern British man of science, who was as supreme in his own line as was Pasteur in France and Von Helmholtz in Germany. Lord Kelvin was born in Belfast in 1824, and came of Scoto- Irish race of Ulster which has been so prolific in genius. His father, Dr. James Thomson, professor of mathematics in the Royal Academical Institute, Belfast, was in 1832 appointed to the chair of mathematics in his alma mater, the old College of Glasgow which formerly stood on the west side of the High Street. His son William, who was destined to play a heroic part in the field of science, became a student of the college while a mere child of eleven or twelve, and astonished the older scholars in his father's class by his preternatural quickness in solving the problems. His talent for mathematics was indubitable, and his father sent him to St. Peter's College, Cambridge, where he graduated as Second Wrangler and first SMith's prizeman in 1845. The senior Wrangler probably owed his triumph to ready writing, for one of the examiners was heard to say that he was unworthy "to cut Thomson's pencils for him," and he has sence been forgotten.

While at Cambridge Thomson began to publish papers on physical subjectsfor example, heat and electricitybut he was active in various directions, and so far from being the pale student, oversome with night work, he was given to open air sports, gained the Silver Sculls, and rowed in the winning boat of the Oxford and Cambridge race. Enrolled a Fellow of St. Peter's, he entered the laboratory of the famous Regnault in Paris, and in 1846 was called to the Chair of Natural Philosophy in his old college at Glasgow, a congenial post, which, in spite of tempting offers, he never quitted. In 1852, he espoused Miss Margaret, a daughter of Mr. Walter Crum, F. R. S., of Rouken Castle, Thornliebank, the famous calico printer, who has distinguised for his investigations on the nature of cotton fibre.

It is impossible to give any but the merest outlines of the inventions of Lord Kelvin. He contributed more than any other man to the success of the Atlantic cable by enunciating the law of retardation whereby engineers were enabled to design a cable, which would give a satisfactory speed to the messages. He invented the mirror instrument for receiving the messages to be sent through the cable. He next produced the siphone recorder, which with the mirror is now employed on most of the submarine cables throughout the world. His most important aid to navigation was the adjustable compass which bears his name. He did more any other electrician to introduce accurate methods of measuring electricity. His machine for predicting the level of the tides in any part of the world was his chief non-electrical invention.

div.head: Eeneh Barrage
div.p: On or about January Ist traffic will be di- verted through the new lock on the west bank at Kxneh Barrage. Vessels should proceed with caution. From 12th April to July 12th, 1908, all navigation will be closed to vessels over 4 1/2 metres beam.

div.p: Lieutenant G.R. Campbell, who wrote the musical play "In Barcelona," which was per- formed at Abbassia last season, has almost completed the book for a pantomine which he intends to produce at the Abbas Theatre dur- , ing the first or second week of February next. The proceeds will be devoted to military charities,

div.head: Benha Murder Trial.
div.p: The Zagazig Court of Assizes has heard the charges against certain natives of the district for the murder of Hag Khadra, a wealthy Benha merchant. The Court found that the murder was committed by Aly Afot, since de- ceased, and sentenced his son and servant to one year's imprisonment for concealing the crime. Farag Effeudi Antoun and his son were declared innocent and acquitted.

div.head: The Mixed Courts.
div.p: The smaller officials of the Mixed Courts at Alexandria, Cairo and Manadurah are much chargined to find that they alone of all em- ployés of the Government have not had their salaries rai of late. Last year the Mixed Court employ4s received one month's pay ex- tra, but under the economical policy of the now régime oven thie consolation is not forth. coming. 'They work longer bours than the other Government employes.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: For -he week ending December 16th. 12 fresh cases of plague occurred in Egypt ; four at Alexandria, three each in the districts of Aga and Deiront and one each at Port-Said and in the district of Tantah. Three deaths have occurred during the past 24 hours at Deiroutand one case has been discharged cured from the same district. The total number o: cases which have been treated during the year now amount to 1221, against 601 for the borresponding period of last year.

div.head: Military Police Dance.
div.p: The Non Commissioned Officers of the Mi- litary Mounted Police gave the first of a se ries of dances at the Gymnasium Baryacks on Thursday evening last. The success of the pre- vious seasons function was repeated, and in respouse to numerous invitations issued, some sixty couples put in an appearance. The de corations of the room were such that har- monized with, and gave a touch of oolour to. the proceedings, while the floor, although a stone surfaee, was in excellent condi- tion. Dancing was kept up from 9 pm. until 2 o'clock the following morning, save for an interval at midnight, when supper was dispensed. The arrgngewents made for the eomfort of the guests were the best and the success of the evening was larvely due to Sergeant Melbourne, Corporal Savage, Cor. porals Harris, Vakley, Sheldrake, and Sharp as a Committee. Corporal Ward efficiently carried out the duties ot M.C.

div.head: Concert at the Railway institute
div.p: To the list of successful evenings promoted by the Entertainments Committee of. the .Egyptian State Railway Institute, Cairo, must be added the concert of last Saturday evening, the excellent programme attracting a large at- tendance, The absence of lady vocalists, notice- able at the previous concert, was remedied by the appearance of Mrs. F. Tyler and Mrs. Melbourne. | was particularly struck with the singing of Mra Tyler, Although possessing a none too powerful voice, it is sweet and unaffected, and moreover she selects songs that are suitable Mrs. Melbourne was heard to advantage in her rendering of "The song that reached my Heart." Uf course Mr. G. Campbell of the Guards brought down the house with his quaint Scotch ditties sung in equally quaint costame, while Corporal McGuire K.0.8.B. was particularly pleasing in Harry Lauder's latest patriotic song "The auld brig of Ayr," which, by the way was introduced to raise subscrip- tions to restrain the destruction of the bridge of that town and maintain it to the memory of Robert Burns. A small dance bron ght a most enjoyoble evening to a close.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON. LA FAVORITA.
div.p: The chief incidents in "La Favorita" were the singing of M. Flachat and the chorus. The chorus in the first and last acts, were as one full voice, breaking or drifting into true and faultless barmony, not merely fulfilling the | ; bald requirements of the score, but achieving its meaning and enhancing its beauty. To me the final chorus of monke and nuns was one of the moat delightful pieces of 'ensemble' singing I have ever heard in opera. M. Flachat fulfilled all and more than [ had hoped for. His voice, always true and full of meaning, took on every shade of colour and passion, renunciation and despair. It is so seldom that the French tenor voice can please without prejudice : it is apt to savour of throat, to be husky, forced, noisy ; but M. Flachat was free from all this and yet bad the characteristic warmth and suggestion of the best 'demi-caractére.' The others dog well enough. M. Gorins (M. Valette" was inscribed for the part, but a change was made) was consistent, but too vigorous : M. Coiglio was certainly good, dignified and emphatic ; Mme. Broglia is ap- parently still unwell, but she was quite ade- quate: her voice accentuates the extreme of the French contralto, constrained, rather forced, apt to be profuse in moments of passion, not always pleasing, but het technique and singing in general seemed good. M.Delmas and Mile Gulberte were excellent in their rather slight parts ; itis so important to fill the lesser parts well, an opera con be so wholly marred by details. The one deadly drawback to the opera was—to my mind—the ballet, not from any intrinsic fault of its own, but because an opera like "La Favorita" is to my poor thinking hardly suitable for such interludes, it needs all it can be given to carry it through, and surely two long ballets are out of place, and should he reserved for some performance when the music and singing is practically non-existent as an interest. There was some such piece given last year in conjunction with "La Fille du Régiment" and I would suggest that certain nights be dedicated to that kind of production; ballet is popular with the majority of the Khedivial audiebce, but surely the minority should not be sacrificed on the altars of tights and twirls. Still, ballet or no ballet, M. Flachat and the chorus would have been worth hearing on any stage, and the highest possible praise is due to them.

div.head: THE EUPHRATES IN FLOOD.
div.p: We have received news from Bagdad that during the heavy rain of 1907 the Euphrates burst its banks near Feluja, and flowed into the Tigris up and downstream of Bagdad. Since then the Turkish authorities have been trying hard to repaire the banks, but it seems likely that this coming flood, if a heavy one, will see the Euphrates cut a new channel for itself straight into the Tigris downstream of Bagdad. In this case the state of the land on the Euphrates will be far more serions than it is to-day with the Euphrates flowing down the Hindia Canal' and leaving the Babylon channel.

div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

div.head: Unrest in Turkey. Conspiracy at Yildiz.
div.p: London, Wednesday. The Vienna correspondent of the Globe says that according to advices from Constantinople a special commission has investigated a conspiracy against the dynasty. It is alleged that Schefket Bey, of the Ministry of Finance, and his two sons headed the plot, but no tangible proof has been discovered. They have been dismissed from their posts. The person most seriously implicated is Saadi Bey, Comptroller of Public Works, who has fled to Cyprus.

div.head: Young Women's Christian Association.
div.p: Through the kind assistance of the manage- ment of the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, the sale of work in connection with the Y.W.C.A., held on Tuesday, proved a record success both socially and financially. The new dining ball had been to the purpose ; and the adjoining ball nied Atel 90 tip Veenalon as's tin eneaxailiin was liberally served and extensively patronized. The sale was open privately by two o'clock so as to enable the native ladies to visit it before the general public, and though many of these were unable to attend owing to the death of Prince Ibrabim, those who did make their appearance were most generous in their purchases. By 3.30, the time for the official opening, the room was very fairly filled: for the list of patronnesses included all the well known residents in the place, who were all present with a numerous assortment of others. Lady Gorst who had kindly consented to open sale arrived soon after and received by Miss Maclnnes, Miss Margerison and the Rev. Hilton Molesworth, and was escorted to the small chair where joined by Lady Blanche Smith for the ceremony. After a hymn and a the Rev. Hilton Molesworth gave speech, illustrating the work of the tion and its influence during the last few and urging the necessity of increasing the funds so as to enable the Association

farther add to its sphere of usefulness. Lady Gorst then declared the sale open, and a vote of thanks was proposed by Crookshank Pasha in the place of Major General Bullock, who was regretably absent through the illness of Mrs. Bullock.

These formalities being over, the real business of the afternoon began and in a very short time the stalls were being shorn of their pretty wares. These were of so varied and so moderate in price that the stall had but little difficulty in disposing of their goods. In addition to the usual Stores of children's garments, linen and woollen goods, cakes, sweets, Oriental and Indian goods, there was a delightful selection of native pottery and English china-ware, presided over by Mrs. Gunter, and Lady Rogers' beaotiful flower stall was augmented by a second on which were piled fine specimens of fruit and vegetables. The children were kept digging for surprises out of a branpie, the cake and sweet stall was extensively patronized by both them and their elders, and as the atter- noom wore on there was a general exodus to the tea room, where the excellent orchestra of the"hotel was to be heard, and urbane waiters were dispensing the much appreciated meal. Business was carried on briskly till 6 o'clock when the afternoon's proceedings were brought to a termination with a few well chosen words of thanks and sympathy with the cause by the Rev. R. Somers, of the Scotch Chorch. Incidently we may mention that this Cairo branch of the Y.W.C.A. has developed on lines not always to be found in the branches at home. Connaught Honse bas grown into what at home would be called a residential club for working women, and as such it has become the very greatest boon to girls who are earning their livelihood in the Cairo, and who are unable or disinclined to live in the more expensive pensions and hotels. The present accomodation permits of some 18 beds, and durmg the winter these are almost always occupied, and the enterprise becomes practi- cally self supporting. The restrictions are so few, and the advantages of Connaught House so many, that it ranks among the most usetol institutions in the country. Lady Cromer was a very great sympathiser in the work so ably carried on by Mists Maclnnes and Miss Margerison, and indeed she still continues her interest, as do all those whe have ever appreciated thé high endeavours of the Cairo branch of the Y.W.C.A.

div.head: Coaling Troubles At Port Said
div.p: Our Port Said correspondent writes under yesterday's date: "Contrary to the rumour circulated here yesterday, the coal discharging and bunkering arabs did not come out or strike this morning. Attempts were made last night to prevent any workmen going to the harbour to work, but there were not serious disturbances. From reports | gather that there isa small party who do not favour another strike. Sbhonld these men hold out from the others when the strike is opened some little distunbance may be expected in the Arab quarter. It appears there was a little scuffle early this morning between the two parties. The police were quickly on the spot and have arrested some of the ring leaders but nothing happened of a sensational charaeter.

div.head: Survey of Erkowit.
div.p: Mr. Boyce, of the Sudan Survey Department, has just completed a minute and detailed survey of Erkowit. He was there for over two months, and for some time had the assistance of Mr. Carson of the same department. They were much hampered in their operations, for at this season of the year a heavy mist hangs over the hills for a great part of the day, completely obliterationg the sun.
December 6.
Tekar's New School.

Mr. J. W. Crowfoot, Assistant Director of Education, arrived here on the 4th inst. and left early this morning by Zambuk for Tokar, to inspect the school recently established there, and which is now attended by over 80 boys.
December 8.
Returns from Furlough.

The S.S. "Salonique" arrived in port this morning from Djeddah and Port Sudan flying the Turkish and pilgrim flage. As the former is now an infected port she has to remain in quarantine, although she appears to have been granted pratique at Port Sudan.

This vessel is owned by Tanani Zada and has been chartered by two merchants here to convey pilgrims to Djeddah. Great numbers of year, especially of the Borno, Felata, and Housa tribes, but they are all known here as Takruris. These devotees to the faith of Islam often take years on the journey, in many instances practically traversing the entire breadth of Africa. Much of it is done on foot, but the railway from Khartoum is now freely patronised.

On arrival here should there be no steamer to take them across, they are conveyed to Djeddah by Zambuk, into which men, women, and children are literally crammed. They are usually embarked during the afternoon, the Zambuk weighing anchor at daybreak, and sailing away with her living freight.
December 10.
A Boundary Conference.

The Governor, Miralai C.J. Hawker Bey, left this morning in the steam tog "Hawk" to meet some Italian officials on the Sudan- Erytrean frontier to confer with them concerning the settlement of the delimitation ot ata certain point where the cattle of the surrounding tribes often cross. As there isa taxon all cattle crossing the frontier the question of boundary has frequently been disputed.

div.head: Sudanese Railways.
div.p: The Sudan railway authorities announce a considerable reduction of freight charges on dhurra and other grains. According to the new tariff, freight charge from Khartoum North to Port Sudan and Suakin, including charges for loading and unloading, will not exceed 12 P.T. per ardeb. This reduction will no doubt encourage the export of grain from the Sudan, and with this encouragement given them, the Sudan grain merchents should be able to secure a large portion of the grain trade of the Red Sea Littoral.

div.head: Echoes of the Boom. An Hotel Case.
div.p: The case of The Tewfik Palace Hotel, Pemberton v. Bentley came on for hearing on Wednesday before the Mixed Tribunals at Cairo. This was an action brought by Willough by Arthur Pemberton to enforce payment of a loan of $6,000 advanced by him to the defendant, Dr. Bentley, in the year 1901 to enable the latter to complete the purchase of the Tewfik Palace, Helouan, from H.H. The Khedivah Mother. Maitre Carton de Wiart, who appeared for the plaintiff, explained the position in a brief and amusing speech. His client, Mr. Pemberton, was introduced to the Defendant in 1901, while the former was on a visit to his brother-in-law, the late Sir Elwin Palmer. Dr. Bentley had entered into a contract to aquire the Twefik Palace with a view to converting it into an Hotel and Sanatorium, to be used in conjunction with his medical practice. Not having the necessary cash in hand, he was obliged to borrow $6,000 to make up the amount asked. viz. $13,000, giving a mortgage on the property to Mr. Pemberton. This mortgage has since become due but remains unpaid. Recently Dr. Bentley, it appeared, had been endeavouring to resell the hotel, and had, during the late "land boom", entered into negotiations with various companies and individuals for this purpose. Ultimately a firm of land agents in Cairo had agreed to give $60,000 for the property subject to a valuation. This firm, in their turn, arranged a resale through a financial group which included a gentleman connected with the Egyptian Estates Limited, to the Helouan Development Company, a condition being that the names of the parties interested should be kept secret by Dr. Bentley, until the completion of the sale to the company.

None of these contracts had in fact been carried out, owing to lack of funds, and Mr. Pemberton has since endeavoured to induce Dr. Bentley to repay him, but without success, the "crisis... from which", said Maitre. Carton, "we are still suffering... having intervened." At this point the president (Judge Tuck) adjourned the case.

The Defendant is represented by Maitre, Bouboulis instructed by Maitre. Devonshire, and Maitre. Dumreicher is watching the case on behalf of other interested parties. We understand that interesting developments are expected in this action, which involves some well- known business men in Cairo.

div.head: Brokers Case.
div.p: Several actions for the recovery of sums of money due to stockbrokers on shares were also mentioned, as well as an action for infringment of patent-right, the conclusion of which was adjourned.

div.head: Hohonovitch v. Brasserie Des Pyramides.
div.p: An action is being brought against the Brasserie des Pyramides by Nicolas Hohono vitch, an ex-employé, for wrongful . dismissal without notice The plaintiff, who entered the company's service in 1905, as buffet manager, at a salary of L.B. 10 per month with com- mission amounting to P.T. 40 per diem, was dismissed at the beginning of the present year in consequence of complaints by customers of the service etc, having been previously asked to leave There was no contract, it was contended on behalf of the com- pany,and the defendants had acted gener- ously in allowing the plaintiff his salary to the end of April, despite the trouble he had given them in refusing to resign, which caused him to be forcibly expelled on January 28th. The plaintiff, represented by Maitre Larmotte, contends that he has suffered severely by dismissal, as he had a restaurant and "pensionuaires" besides the cold |unch bar mentioned by the defence.

Here the president directed that the action should stand over, and the sitting closed with the sale by auction of certain lands, the con- tracts relating to which bad not been fulfilled, another case relating to the sale of Wakf pro- perty being adjourned.
The "Egypt" arrived here this afternoon and all her passengers are enthusiastic about the voyage and comfort of the boat. Her arrival also occasioned great interest here.

Among the well known people expected at the Winter Palace Hotel for Christmas are the Hon. Mr. Iddings, the American Diplo- matic Agent and Consul General at Cairo, and Count Bernsdorff, the German Minister, with their families. Miss Danlop, Miss Mal, Dr. and Mr. T. Hope Lewis, Miss F. S. M. Baker, Miss Merrick, Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Winteretz, Clowes and party, Dr. and Mrs. Fall, Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Nobi, and Mrs. H. A. Williams, Mr. W. Donald, Mr. H. A. Armour, Miss Laura A. Barnett, the Hon. Edith Gibbs and family, and Mr. Russell lea and family. The weather continues perfect and everyone is rejoicing in the absence of flies and mosquitoes.

div.head: Egyptian Mail Steamship Co. Ltd.
div.p: The tourist office of the Hamburg-American Line, who are the general passenger Agents in Egypt for the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co, Ltd. have just opened a new passenger office in St. Catherine square, Alexandria. The Agent in charge will be Mr. A. Stroes of the well-known firm of that name.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Some Italian Republican and Socialist newspapers have stated that the visit of the Duchess of Aosta to Egypt was due to political reasons, and is a quasi-exile because the Princess attended the recent marriage at Wood Norton of Don Carlos de BOurbon and Princess Louise of France. The sister of the Duchess married the son of the Count of Casserta, who claims the throne of Naples as brother of King Francesco 3. The Duchess is the wife of a Prince of the House of Savoy, who resides in the Royal Palace at Naples and yet her sister is the daughter in law of the claimant to the throne of Naples, who as Count of Caserta occupied the place of honour at the wedding banquet. The presence of the Duchess caused great offence in Rome and so the Duchess has come for a prolonged stay in Egypt. These reports in the Italian press are declared to be quite baseless, for the Duchess's visit to Egypt is solely due to her ill-health.
The earl and contess Rothes have arrived at the Savoy Hotel. Their party includes Lady Mildred Leslie, Mrs. Fellowes, Captain Devenish, Mr. H. Richardson and Mr. A. Chrichton.

The Marquis of Angesey, Count and Countes Wachtmeister, and Mr. and Mrs. Stapledon Cotton arrived at the Savoy Palace Hotel, Alexandria, on Tuesday afternoon. Other arrivals at this hotel include, Lord Norreys, De Martino Bey, Warriff Pasha, Nubar Pasha, Adly Pasha, Fonad Pasha, Saddik Bey, Mr. Antrauikian, Mr. Avionitis, Mr. Reyntier, Mr. Crighton, Mr. Goldechmitt, Mrs. Irene Harvey, Mr. Shepard, Dr. Veromoff, Mme Friedrich, Mr. Schnabel, Mr. and Mrs. Blunt Sutton, Mr. Couturier, Mr. Dugonfant, Mr. Delanoy, Mr. and Mrs. Lampolough, Mme Privilgio, Mme Nomico, Mlle Armida Bruchi, Mme Kruscienski Mr. Bass, Mr. Green.

Photius I. the Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, and the Hellenic Consul General and the staff of the Consulate attended a mass this morning at the Patriarchat Church of Saint Saba in honour of the Onomastic Feast of the EMperor of Russia, to-day being St. Nicholas day.
Mr. Binney and Lady Majorie Binney are epected by the "Heliopolis" next week, and should arrive at the Savoy on Xmas day.
Mr. A. J. Beckwith with Mrs. and Miss Beckwith are expected at the same time.
Countess Chamare is also expected at the Savoy shortly.
Lady and Miss Allen have left 5, Cadogan-place for Egypt, and will not be returning till the spring.
The Hon. A. Pelham and Lady Pelham left Suez yesterday afternoon for Khartoum via Port Sudan by the Khedivial Mail Company's express steamer "Prince Abbas."
Judge and Mrs. Cator left for Constantinople yesterday by the S.S. "Ismailia."

Other passengers by the "Ismailia" were Mr. Silley, Mr. and Mrs. Vallois, Mohsen Bey Fawai, Mr. and Mrs. Makray, Mr. Vansild, Mr. Vassocostich, and Mrs Roux de Vence, Mr D. Simitopoulo, Mr. Rabild, Mr. Parasakiva Rizaki, Mohamed Effendi Sabri, Mr. Gustave Lewall, and others.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: LA séance de ce matin a ete une repetition de celle d'hier. Tout le monde etant vendeur, il ne se traite evidemment que des affaires occasionnelles et insignifiantes, et cela au prix d'une nouvelle reduction de la cote. La plupart des titres les plus deprecies etant irrealisables, l'epargue qui a un besoin immediat de numraire se rejette sur les titres d'un echange plus facile, entre autres sur l'obligation credit foncier egyptien dont la nouvelle est au pair a 250 tr. et l'ancienne a 279 fr. 50. Ceci demontre qu'aux grands maux il faut les grands remedes. On a voulu temporiser dans l'attente d'une reprise avec des situations equivoques qui de mandaient une liquidating dans des conditions encore plus defavorables. Esperons que les interesses comprendront enfin qu'il est inutile et meme dangereux de remettre a plus tard une operation urgente, et un mot, qu'il vaut mieux faire la part du feu que de tout perdre en cherchant a tout sauver.
Ce n'est d'alilleurs qu' a la suite de ces liquidations volontaires ou forcees de la masse des engagements surchagers qu'on peut esperer un relevement serieux et durable.

div.head: The Persian Crisis. Manifesto to Powers.

div.p: In accordance with a resolution passed in Parliament the Persian people have addressed a manifesto to the Powers declaring that the young Shah is inflaenced by persons accnstomed to the old despotic regime and is violating the Constitution. They appeal to the nations of the world not to allow the rights of the people to be down rodden but to support the people in defending them. The shops are still closed. ( Reuter)

The "Times" learns from Teheran that the reactionaries, augmented by a thousand 'roughs, hold the Gun Square in the vicinity of the palace. 10,000 nationalists have erected barricades round the Parliament building and are acting on the defensive. (Reuter)
The Chamber of Deputies has ratified the arrest of M. Nasi. (Havas)

Chamber of Deputies. The Chamber by 239 votes to 91 resolved to thaintain the legality of the arrest of Nasi. The Government abstained from taking part in the discussion as the question was one Parliamentary prerogative. ( Reuter )
The Civil Court has disposed of the Ullmo case and the dos-ier has been referred to the Marine Minister. ( Havas)
M. Regnault has visited the King who expressed his great satisfaction with the agreement between France and Spain. ( Havas )
The Kaiser will visit Monaco during his cruise in the 'Mediterranean in the spring. ( Havas)
Cricket. There was no play owing to rain.
( Reuter)
See
The first parliament has met. The members have been sworn in. ( Reuter)
The students agitation has ceased. The University will reopen after Christmas.
( Reuter)
A wireless telephonic message was sent yesterday from here to Copenhagen. (Reuter)
Admiral Evans, after the Pacitic fleet had sailed, announced that he would return via Suez. The press here is heatedly discussing as to whether the ships are as efficient as supposed.
( Reuter )

div.head: AMERICAN MONEY PANIC. LABOUR FEDERATION'S RESOLUTION.

div.p: Mr. Gompers, President of the Federation of | i Labour, speaking at a en ae given in honour of the Civic Federation, notified employers that workmen would not consent to any reduc- tion in wages as a result of the money panic, | i for which they were not responsible. (Reuter)
The jewellers' National Bank at Northattle- boro (Massachusetts), with deposita of over 1,000,000 dollars remains unopened The cash- ier has committed suicide. ( Reuter)
Lieutenant Wood has resigned under protest.
( Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

It is becoming increasingly evident that Lombard Street must be prepared for stiff discount rates for some weeks to come. In the first place, the task of clearing up the wreckage in America isa slow process. Further failures have taken place this week, and cash is re- turning only very slowly into circulation. The preminom of gold still continues, and further shipments from this side are expected. So far as can be gathered, the banks are still retaining the paper currency, notwithstanding that the date fixed for the renewal of cash payments passed some ten days ago.

South America is also likely to require a substantial quantity of gold in the near future. The crops there are reported to be excellent, and will probably be sold at high prices, so that London will have to fakea large share in providing the'necessary funds. Another point to be reckoned with in considering the future movements of discoont rates is the serious financial position in Germany. As already reported in your columns, the Budget recently large deficit, in spite of economy in the varions departments, and - Government were compelled to a million of the Sinking Fund for Imperial Debt in order to reduce the deficit. It is therefore probable that gold will go to Berlin hefore the end of the year.

One bright feature in the outlook is the cessation of the demands for Egypt, and it is hoped that the gold you have already obtained will be safficient to finance the crop. Indeed we are-given to understand that we may anti- cipate a return of the precious metal from Egypt in January, and that your banks have several millions of gold in their coffers in Egypt ; this being so, they should be more ready to make advances on Egyptian Stocks and Shares in your markets, all of which should tend to improve the situation. The position of the. Bank of England has undergone a substantial improvement during the past week, the increase' in the re- serve amounting to £1,767,823, bringing the total to £23,674,013, which compares with £22.748,055 in the corresponding week of 1906. The proportion to liabilities is up 2.93 on the week, being now 46.95, againét 47.02 last year. The increase in coin and bullion is £1,400,000, and the note circulation has con- tracted to the extent of nearly £360,000. Other Securities have been reduced by 1} millions, as the result of the maturing of bills at the Bank, but Public Deposits have declined £200,000. Other Securities are up £727,376.

The money market has continned easy throughout the week, and overnight accomoda- tion realises only 4 to 44 per cent. Discount rates are very firm, the rate for three months' paper being round about 6 per cent. The price of bar gold was fixed on Monday #d. lower than last week, and is now quoted 77/103.

div.head: Telegrams
div.p: Sliver

The- silver market has fallen away again this week, the , quotation for immediate delivery being down to 25 on Tuesday. On Wednesday the tone was better, and the price recovered 3/8, but yesterday it was again down to 25
The Stock Markets.

A much quieter tone has prevailed on the Stock Exchange during the past week. One reason for this is that the arrangement of the account has occupied a good deal of time, and in the early part of the week there was little disposition to open new commitments until this was out of the way, and the real extent of the speculative position made known. Dealings during the fortnight has been on a fairly large scale, and it was evident that the speculators had been active. America continues an unsettling feature, the reports from the otherside being anything but bright. There have been more important failures, and the frequency of the tragedies traceable to the crisis serve to accentuate the feeling of depression. There is a feeling here that further liquidation of unsound positions must take place before any real improvement in the situation can be expected.

The near approach of the Christmas holidays is also operating against active dealings. The arrangement proposed between the Great Northern and Great Central Railways continues to excite much discussion. No official statement of the proposals has yet been published, but what are regarded as probable accurate forecasts have appeared in several papers, and the general opinion appears to be that what the two companies propose to carry out is nothing less than the formation of a trust, both concerns being placed under one manager, and the recipts and expenses pooled. A considerable saving in working expenses would thus be affected, and it is probable that similar arrangments between some of the other companies would quickly follow.
Consols.

Gilt-edged stocks were dull at the beginning, and Consols fell away. During the past two or three days the market, has been quiet, and Consols closed last night at 82, }§. To-day Consols have shed 1/16 for cash and account.
Foreign Bonds.

The foreign market has been quiet. Russians have not shown much movement, and last night's closing prices were practically anchan- ged on the week. Japanese issues have been rather offered, and close lower, the First Series of 44 1/2% closing last night at 90 1/4, as compared with 90 5/8 a week ago. To-day these have gained 1/8.
Russian Fives have to-day avanced 3/4 to 90,
and the Foors 1/2 to 82 1/4}
Home Rallis.

During the past account there have been heavy dealings in home railway shares, es- pecially in Great Northern and Great Central and there has been no small amount of gramb ling at the heavy contangoe rates charged by the banks. On the heavy lines these were us- ually about 8 per cent. bat in the case of the two companies mentioned above the rates were as high as 12 1/2 and 15%, thus pointing to the existence of a large speculative account. There were extensive dealings in York Deferred on Monday, and the price at one time went to 48. 1/16. but profit taking has since caused a decline. Yesterday these shares closed with a loss of 5/8, at 47 1/8.
Americans.

Shares in this market, show no decided im- proévement, and have moved spasmodically For the most part changes are against holders The situation is still too uncertain to permit of much business being done in Americans on this side. Yesterday the market brightened a little on the announcement that as President Mr. Roosevelt had definitely decided not to stand for re-election, but the buying was chiefly attributed to nervous bears.
Americans bave relapsed again to-day, New
York central and Milwavkee are 1 1/2 lower at 98
and 105 1/2, and Unions 1/2 at 119 1/2.
Egyptians.
Bittle business has been done in Egyptians
during the past week, and prices are almost
unchanged, with the exception of Daira Sanieh,
which, after being as good as 13 1/4 bayers fell
away yesterday to 12 3/4 without finding angers.
To-night these close at 12 1/2-13. The Deferred
remain round about 65-70. New Egyptian
have been in request, and rose to 1/2 bid,
closing either side of this price
National Bank are fairly steady at 20 1/3-1/2,
and Agricultural Bank at 7, 15/16. The 3 1/2%.

Estates, and they each close 38/8-4. Union
Fonciere are 4 ½- 3/4, and Land Bank 7 1/4-1/2. Sidi
Salem are offered at 2 1/4 without reply.
Mining.
Kaffirs were heavy in the early part of the
week, partly as the result of liquidation from
the Continent and lack of support here. Prices
generally moved downards, bat there was a
decidedly firmer tone yesterday. The dividend
announcements had a good effect, and farther
strength was given tothe market by the fact
that Paris had changed from a seller to a
Goldfields rose 3/32 to 3, 5/16 Premier Deferred
1/8 to 8, and Modders 1/8 to 5, 11/16.
Kaffirs have been neglected to-day.
There is no business doing in Egyptian mining shares.
The closing prices to-night are as follows:

div.head: St. Vitus Dance
div.p: DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS
INVALUABLE FOR CHILDREN.
St. Vitos' Dance is a terrible nervous
malady which brings despair to many parents.
Yet it is a complaint which is cored rapidly
and completely by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills
-| for Pale People, incontrovertible evidence of
which has been received in many testimonials.
A short whileago M.A. Duteil, well known at
Pontorson (Manche), informed us of the cure
of his son, in the letter given below :
"For more than a year, my son Georges,
. | aged eleven years, was a victim of St. Vitas'
Mr. | Dance, and in spite of all our care his condition
. | became worse and worse. The child became
exhausted, and naturally we were greatly
upset. Happily, however, we were advised
to give him Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. From
the first box it was easy to see that he was
getting better. In all he took three boxes, and
completely cured, he was soon able to return
to school. His health is now excellent, he eats
well, and his appearance is healthy. He no
longer his troublesome nights and his nervous
agitation has disappeared. We were the more
grateful for this cure because it was accom-
plished at the time when he was to go for his
would be wise to give their little ones Dr. Wil-
liams' Pink Pills doring their tender years,
and thus safeguard them against the many
aliments to which they are susceptible at this
epoch.
Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People are
good for adults as well as juniors. They cure
M. Georges Duteil, (Cl. Mornicne, Pontorson. )
Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T.
18 the box and P.T. 70 tor six boxes.

Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau
Techuique od il peut étre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h. a midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront tre adressées sons pli cacheté 4 Monsieur |'Administratear de la
Municipalité avant le 24 Décembre 1907,
Elles pourront également étre déposées en
séance de la Délégation le méme jour a
5h. p.m.
L'envoppe devra porter en outre la mention:
"Soumission pour "Fourniture tombe-
reaux."

d'aprés les conditions du cahier des charges devra é@tre remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant |'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 24 décembre 4
midi.
